Posts.Content: Hi Pat, you sound just like I did after I had my first chemo treatment. I went for 17 rounds, and when I went back for the 2nd one I broke down and cried saying I couldn't do it ... My oncologist, the best in the world, was always so sensitive and caring and told me he perfectly understood because he had been on chemo before. He told me to commit to one session at a time, and that's how I did it. I dind't even think about all the remaining sessions. I only counted "one more", and did it. I also completely lowered my expectations about how I was going to feel and behave after chemo, and allowed myself to stay in bed for 7 straight days after each round. Yes, it took me 7 days to be able to walk on my own and even think clearly after every round, but my oncologist said that was completely normal given my sensitivity to drugs, and that if that was what my body needed to do to recover, then that was it. Pat, I wish I could give you a magic recipe, but I don't have one. You have to do this because it's your way to health and survival. You cannot give cancer another chance. Rest, rest, rest, and when feeling good, do what you want. One session at a time, and you'll get done. Yes, it gets done!!! I'm praying for you.
Posts.Title: How can I handle Chemo better?

Posts.Content: I had breast cancer (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma) in both breasts two years ago. I had to have bilateral mastectomies. At first I noticed a large lump that on the mammogram showed to be just full of water, but the mammogram showed two smaller tumors in the other breasts, it was cancer. More mammograms and ultrasounds did not find any additional tumors in either breast. I had to have an MRI to make sure everything was fine, and it was then that two more tumors were seeing in the other breast. Both tumors were cancerous as well. I had dense breast tissue, so the small tumors couldn't be seen by mammograms. If you feel something is wrong, it probably is. Ask to have an MRI to make sure. I keep you in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: LinDe, How are you doing right now? I pray that you are getting better from the infection. Cancer is scary, that's for sure. I had it 2 years ago. I finished chemo 1 year ago, after having bilateral mastectomies for invasive ductal carcinoma in both breasts. I was terrified from the moment I was told I needed to have the first 3 biopsies. It took me a long time to get hold of my fears, and even now I still have bad moments. It takes time to realize that this monster gets the best of you, of your family and loved ones, if you allow it. You have to gather your courage and determination to decide that even in the worst moments you will not allow cancer to rob you of hope and faith. You are not alone. You are surrounded by all of us who went through this before, and those who are going through it right now. Please write again and let me know how you are doing. Monica

Posts.Title: I'm scared and need support

Posts.Content: I have been in your shoes before, and yes, it is scary and we all need support at a time like this. I had breast cancer 2 years ago, and had it in both breasts. I had to have 5 biopsies to determine the status of all the tumors. The biopsies were painless. Don't let fear of the procedures take the best of you, because the biopsies are painless. The doctor will give you local anesthesia and you will be fine. Even the first sting of the anesthesia is very minimal. It may take you between 1 and 2 hours to be completely done with the procedure. There was a little discomfort after the local anesthesia wore off, but with Tylenol and an ice pack I did fine. The worst part is waiting for the results. Make sure you have a loved one with you when you go in to see your doctor for the results.There are many of us praying for you right now. Please let me know about the results.  Praying for you, Monica
Posts.Title: I'm scared and need support

Posts.Content: On 4/24/2009 Goodattitude wrote: I, too, had severe side effects from Arimidex.  I took it for six months then was switched to Tamoxiphin and got worse.  I gained 35 lbs, but I believe it was from the Chemo.  I developed high blood pressure, high cholesterol and was depressed, tired and listless.  I decided to choose quality of life instead, knowing that this perhaps may be the wrong decision and for me it was.  It's been three years and I was just diagnosed with breast cancer again in the other breast.  First time I had a partial masectomy.  This time I have no choice but to have a complete masectomy.  I know many women that have and have not had side effects.  You've dealt with this for 3 years, why not hang in there for 2 more?  The weight will come off eventually.  It took me one year to lose the weight.  This time my doc. says we'll try Femara.  My eldester sister who also had the same type of breast cancer took Femara without any side effects and she was 90lbs. Think smartly and good luck.   On 4/22/2009 dove111 wrote: I was on arimidex for 3 years and after having all kinds of side affects decided quality of life was more important than being sick all the time.  I have gained 45 lbs., and haven't lost anything after three weeks of weight watchers, in fact I gained 3 lbs.  Has anyone else had this issue and has anyone stopped treatment early due to side affects?   cindy       My heart sunk when I read you got diagnosed again. What a challenge!! I keep you in my thoughts and prayers. Don't second guess yourself. You made the decision that was right for you at the time you made it, and that's that. I got breast cancer in both breasts at the same time, with no family history of it ever. I don't have any genes to blame either. So, this monster just attacks whenever. Stay strong and faithful. Monica
Posts.Title: Arimidex and side affects

Posts.Content: I finished chemo 1 year ago and was put on Arimidex first, and the side effects (serious joint pain) were intolerable. I was switched to Aromacin, and it did take me several months to get rid of the pain, but I'm doing much, much better now. I still have other side effects, but nothing compared to Arimidex. Talk to your doctor about Aromacin, maybe you could switch to that medication. The other thing that helps me a lot with pain management is exercise. I get on the treadmill seven days a week, rain, snow or ice. I get anywhere between 3 and 5 miles every day. Believe me, the more I walk, the less pain I have, and sleeping through the night is a breeze. Whenever you feel up to it, try getting on a regular walk schedule, it will help a lot. Good luck!!! You are in my thoughs and prayers.
Posts.Title: Arimidex and side affects

Posts.Content: Yes, I'm awake because my family (hubby and kids) are sleeping now, so I have a special time to get in touch with the loving people on this site. I do pray that what you have is nothing else than the consequences of the radiation. Don't forget to let me know about the results. Monica

You and your daughter in law are in my prayers, and I hope you never again have to be through such an ordeal without receiving appropriate pain medication. Monica

Posts.Title: another lump

Posts.Content: Two years ago, my grandma and my father passed away within two weeks of each other. At the same time, I was diagnosed with bilateral breast cancer. At the time, I also felt completely overwhelmed by life and kept asking myself why all these terrible things had to happen all at once. I do not expect not to go through tragedy, but seriously, everything at once? Why? I was angry, not at God, but at life itself, and the only thing that made sense to me was the realization that God did not send me bad things, and that the universe is very imperfect. If we lived in a perfect universe, we wouldn't have cancer, deaths, or unhappiness. It is simply the imperfection of the universe what gave me (and my family) such a terrible time. And this imperfect universe spares nobody. It is your right to feel completely overwhelmed, sad, angry and anything else you feel because you are in a terrible situation. Many of us have no idea what it is like to be in your shoes. I admire your courage to honestly tell us what you are feeling. We care, we really do. Please write often. Monica
Posts.Title: Both my Parents Have Cancer

Posts.Content: Two years ago, my grandma and my father passed away within two weeks of each other. At the same time, I was diagnosed with bilateral breast cancer. I was angry, not at God, but at life itself, and the only thing that made sense to me was the realization that God did not send me bad things, and that the universe is very imperfect. Posts.Title: Both my Parents Have Cancer

Posts.Content: Roseann, thank you so much for replying. My only guess is that different doctors approach the removal of ovaries differently, depending on family history, type of breast cancer, and results of genetic testing. I was advised by my oncologist, the geneticist, and two additional consulting oncologists from one of the Mayo Clinics in Florida that my chances of getting ovarian cancer would be the same as any other woman without breast cancer. Of course, the ultimate decision of getting the surgery or not was mine. By all means, you should do what will give you peace of mind and better quality of life. It is very scary to live our days thingking about if and when the monster will return. I wish you the best, and keep you in my prayers. Monica
Posts.Title: breast cancer patient advised to undergo genetic testing

Posts.Content: I had breast cancer in both breasts in 2007, and had several tumors in each breast, so my only option was to have bilateral mastectomies. My oncologist strongly recommended that I had genetic testing, which I did. My insurance covered the bill, which was about 3,000, and the results came back in 2 weeks. I tested negative for the genes so my oncologist stated that I did not need to have my ovaries removed. I wish you and your wife the best, and I keep you in my prayers.
Posts.Title: breast cancer patient advised to undergo genetic testing
